Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ABI Innovation: Plant Genotype-Phenotype (G2P) Association Discovery via Integrative Genome-scale Biological Network & Genome-wide Association Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the mechanisms of genotype and phenotype (G2P) associations has been an important and challenging task in modern biology. The challenge lies in the high-dimensional gene variables and the complexity of gene regulation and interactions that collectively define particular phenotypes (also called traits). The project will develop innovative methods, tools and bioinformatics systems to decipher the plant G2P associations through integrative genome-scale biological network and genome-wide association analysis. A breakthrough in this work will lead to a systems-level understanding of how biological processes, pathways and complex traits in plants are hierarchically regulated. Advancing such fundamental knowledge will greatly benefit modern genome-assisted plant breeding by providing the underlying regulatory mechanisms and key regulators of agriculturally important traits. This in turn will have great potential to be translated into new means of improving plant quality and production for agriculture, thus benefiting society as a whole. Cutting-edge technologies will be developed to study G2P associations in plants, providing excellent opportunities for training undergraduates, graduates and postdocs in interdisciplinary fields such as computational biology, bioinformatics, plant genomics, and statistical genetics, at the three institutes. Underrepresented minorities and women will be especially targeted in the recruitment of the project. The research will form the basis of the proposed educational workshops centering on bioinformatics and statistical genetics. Creative and innovative hands-on outreach activities will be arranged through the three institutes? outreach programs with local K-12 schools to inspire young minds to become bioinformatics scientists.

Innovative methods will be developed to analyze genome-scale biological networks and genome-wide associations through a fully integrated bioinformatics platform, enabling the discovery of G2P associations in plants. Specific aims of the project include 1) to develop novel top-down and bottom-up graphical Gaussian model (GGM) algorithms to reconstruct the hierarchical gene networks that control biological processes and pathways; 2) to develop models and algorithms that enable large-scale marker-trait association analysis with high precision using novel statistical genetics approaches; and 3) to develop a Graph-search-empowered integrative bioinformatics platform to facilitate the integration, deciphering and discovery of G2P associations. To validate our approaches and tools, public data from genome-wide plant 'omics' studies and genome-wide association studies (GWAS) will be integrated and analyzed, associating traits with SNP markers and fine-tuning the prediction of phenotype-associated hierarchical and/or pleiotropic regulators and functional networks. The novel knowledge and analytic methods and tools yielded from this project will be disseminated into the public at large through presentations, publications and web applications. All the tools and data resources will be made freely available at http://plantgrn.org/ to the plant research communities, accelerating plant bioinformatics and plant science research, education and applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report ? NSF Awards# 1458130

Project Title: Collaborative Research: ABI Innovation: Plant Genotype-Phenotype (G2P) Association Discovery via Integrative Genome-scale Biological Network & Genome-wide Association Analysis

Recipient Organization:  Michigan Technological University

Project/Grant: 07/01/2015 to 06/30/2019

PI:  Hairong Wei

This project developed a top-down and two bottom-up statistical methods for constructing multi-layered gene regulatory networks using high throughput omics data. These methods enable us to decipher the observed phenotypes directly from the genotypes that are represented by multi-layered gene regulatory networks, based on which the information regarding how complex traits and biological processes are regulated can be drawn. An experimental validation and a subsequent practical application of the methods to a real data proved the high accuracy of the methods in building gene network because the majority of regulatory relationships in the inferred networks were experimentally verifiable.   

This project also developed a novel and effective statistical method for recognition of pathway regulators from high throughput omics data. The method is capable of identifying most regulatory genes that are associated with a biological pathway based on their mathematical relevance in the data.  In-silico validation by identifying known positive regulators of several pathways in both animals and plants suggested the high efficiency and very usefulness of the method.  

Finally, the project developed a method for identifying both common and unique hub regulators by jointly constructing a unified genetic network using data from two or more sources, which can be two or more types of tissues, the same type of tissue in two or more different environmental conditions or the same type of tissue in two or more different developmental stages. The method combined machine learning with statistics theories to enable us to identify both common and tissue/condition/stage-specific hub regulators. Therefore, it is instrumental in discovering novel knowledge from spatial and/or temporal multi-source omics data sets.  

This project integrated the most recent statistical and machine learning cutting-edge technologies into the study of phenotype and genotype  relationships. All the tools and data resources have been made freely available to the plant/animal research communities through publications, open source software, and three web applications, which can be used to facilitate bioinformatics research and education. This project trained two Ph.D. students and offered two educational workshops centering on bioinformatics and statistical analysis of high throughput omics data. The novel knowledge and skills yielded from this project have been disseminated into the public domain through our synergistic activities.

The project yielded seven publications and three online tools. The five most significant and/or relevant publication are: (1) Gunasekara et al. 2018. Nucleic Acids Res.46(11):e67 (PMID: 29579132); (2) Wei, H. 2017. Briefings in Bioinformatics (PMID: 29186304); (3) Deng et al. 2018. Bioinformatics 34(20):3470-3478 (PMID: 29718187); (4) Deng et al., 2017. PloS ONE 12(2):e0171532(PMID:28158291); (5) Kumari et al. 2016. BMC Bioinformatics 17: 132 (PMID:26993098). The three Web tools are: (1) Top-down and Bottom-up GGM algorithms: http://sys.bio.mtu.edu/topdown/; (2) TF-Miner: http://sys.bio.mtu.edu/cluster/; (3) exactSearch http://sys.bio.mtu.edu/motif/.
